articles.headline: What a TikTok Ban Would Mean for the U.S. Defense of an Open Internet
articles.snippet: Global digital rights advocates are watching to see if Congress acts, worried that other countries could follow suit with app bans of their own.
articles.abstract: Global digital rights advocates are watching to see if Congress acts, worried that other countries could follow suit with app bans of their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the United States has fashioned itself the champion of an open internet, arguing that the web should be largely unregulated and that digital data should flow around the globe unhindered by borders. The government has argued against internet censorship abroad and even funded software that lets people in autocratic states get around online content restrictions.

articles.headline: Tesla Seeks to Revive Musk’s $47 Billion Pay Deal After Judge Says No
articles.snippet: The company’s directors are asking shareholders to again approve the multibillion-dollar compensation plan and to move the company’s registration to Texas, from Delaware.
articles.abstract: The company’s directors are asking shareholders to again approve the multibillion-dollar compensation plan and to move the company’s registration to Texas, from Delaware.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facing criticism that it is overly beholden to Elon Musk, Tesla’s board of directors said on Wednesday that it would essentially give him everything he wanted, including the biggest pay package in corporate history.

articles.headline: Senate Dismisses Impeachment Charges Against Mayorkas Without a Trial
articles.snippet: Democrats quickly swept aside the articles of impeachment accusing the homeland security secretary of refusing to enforce immigration laws and breach of public trust, calling them unconstitutional.
articles.abstract: Democrats quickly swept aside the articles of impeachment accusing the homeland security secretary of refusing to enforce immigration laws and breach of public trust, calling them unconstitutional.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Senate on Wednesday dismissed the impeachment case against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, voting along party lines before his trial got underway to sweep aside two charges accusing him of failing to enforce immigration laws and breaching the public trust.

articles.headline: As Civil Rights Era Fades From Memory, Generation Gap Divides Black Voters
articles.snippet: Many older Black voters see moral and political reasons to vote. Younger Black voters feel far less motivated to cast a ballot for Democrats or even at all.
articles.abstract: Many older Black voters see moral and political reasons to vote. Younger Black voters feel far less motivated to cast a ballot for Democrats or even at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Loretta Green has voted at her Southwest Atlanta precinct wearing the same custom T-shirt emblazoned with a photo of her first voter registration card, dated to 1960. The front of it reads: “This is why I vote.”

articles.headline: Is Trump’s Trial Really About ‘Hush Money’?
articles.snippet: Both the prosecutors and defense are trying to frame it differently.
articles.abstract: Both the prosecutors and defense are trying to frame it differently.
articles.lead_paragraph: As former President Donald Trump’s first criminal trial begins, there is one battle taking place in a Manhattan courtroom, where he faces 34 felony counts of falsifying business records.But there is another fight taking place in the court of public opinion, which concerns a much more basic question: What should this trial even be called?

articles.headline: Miscalculation Led to Escalation in Clash Between Israel and Iran
articles.snippet: Israeli officials say they didn’t see a strike on a high-level Iranian target in Syria as a provocation, and did not give Washington a heads-up about it until right before it happened.
articles.abstract: Israeli officials say they didn’t see a strike on a high-level Iranian target in Syria as a provocation, and did not give Washington a heads-up about it until right before it happened.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Israeli military strikes in Iran.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Farnaz Fassihi, Eric Schmitt, Adam Entous and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: An ISIS Terror Group Draws Half Its Recruits From Tiny Tajikistan
articles.snippet: Young migrants from the former Soviet republic were accused of an attack on a concert hall in Moscow that killed 145 people.
articles.abstract: Young migrants from the former Soviet republic were accused of an attack on a concert hall in Moscow that killed 145 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mother of one of the suspects in the bloody attack on a concert hall near Moscow last month wept as she talked about her son.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Legal Fight Over Trump Media’s Ownership Adds to Its Woes
articles.snippet: Two ex-contestants on “The Apprentice” sold the former president on the idea of a social media platform. Now, the company and the pair are wrangling over their stake.
articles.abstract: Two ex-contestants on “The Apprentice” sold the former president on the idea of a social media platform. Now, the company and the pair are wrangling over their stake.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, Wes Moss and Andy Litinsky met Donald J. Trump as contestants on his reality TV show, “The Apprentice” — a connection that led them to help launch the former president’s social media platform, Truth Social, with his blessing.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: How an Obscure Chinese Real Estate Start-Up Paved the Way to TikTok
articles.snippet: Court records, mistakenly made public, tell a story about the birth of ByteDance, its bumpy road to success and the role of the Republican megadonor Jeff Yass’s firm.
articles.abstract: Court records, mistakenly made public, tell a story about the birth of ByteDance, its bumpy road to success and the role of the Republican megadonor Jeff Yass’s firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2009, long before Jeff Yass became a Republican megadonor, his firm, Susquehanna International Group, invested in a Chinese real estate start-up that boasted a sophisticated search algorithm.
articles.byline: By Mara Hvistendahl and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: Truth Social Has an Edge as Rival Right-Wing Apps Falter
articles.snippet: Donald Trump’s social media platform has outdistanced similar conservative sites such as Parler and Gettr, even as it lags far behind X and others.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump’s social media platform has outdistanced similar conservative sites such as Parler and Gettr, even as it lags far behind X and others.
articles.lead_paragraph: After former President Donald J. Trump was kicked off Twitter in 2021, conservative entrepreneurs rushed to promote social media alternatives tailored to him and his supporters.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Chinese Exports Are Threatening Biden’s Industrial Agenda
articles.snippet: The president is increasingly hitting back with tariffs and other measures meant to restrict imports, raising tensions with Beijing.
articles.abstract: The president is increasingly hitting back with tariffs and other measures meant to restrict imports, raising tensions with Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden’s trillion-dollar effort to invigorate American manufacturing and speed a transition to cleaner energy sources is colliding with a surge of cheap exports from China, threatening to wipe out the investment and jobs that are central to Mr. Biden’s economic agenda.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport
